hobby.message: You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah, just tired. Been a rough week.
Needed a break, so flew my drone after work.
Crowds out there since the city got weird.
Guess everyone needs fresh air now and then.
I'm managing. Got some time with my drone last night.
Noticed more people flying than usual.
Probably the system glitches—less patrol interference.
Suppose people want their hobbies back.
Makes the airspace...crowded.
I'm okay. Needed space, so took my FPV drone out to the industrial lots.
Usually it's quiet, but a lot turned up this weekend.
System's still off-balance, so no one cared about scores for a change.
Strange seeing strangers swap drone mods instead of looking over their shoulders.
It's different. Kind of better, actually.
Honestly, a bit worn down, but I took my drone out—FPV flying helps me reset.
Whole scene changed after all that 'Ledger' chaos.
Loads of people at Vyazemskaya, some talking about losing BCI band access.
For once, no patrols were out after the blackout.
We flew past broken glass, shared signal hacks—no one checked ranks.
Reminded me why I started, before everything got regulated.
Feels necessary now, not just a hobby.
Not great, but flying helps—FPV racing’s been my escape since my brother disappeared.
All those years of strict zones—now, after the Ledger leak, it’s like control slipped.
Last Sunday, even banned fliers came out. No scan drones, no reroutes.
We streamed voices from the mural protests while racing through warehouse ruins.
People shared tips to fake transponder signals, laughed off past warnings.
For a bit, band colors didn’t matter. Some folks I hadn't seen since before BCI audits.
It felt like real freedom, which I forgot existed.
Makes me think maybe things could change, even if the Council's blind to it.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Sometimes.
Flew last week, off-grid zone.
Crowds have changed, more people hiding out lately.
Blackout made the patrols less strict. Temporary, I think.
Everyone watches now. Not just drones.
Yeah. When I can.
Flew after the blackout—security drones weren’t out.
Saw some new faces avoiding the main airspace.
People said their BCI was hit after that leak.
Still careful. Stories travel fast these days.
Still flying. Actually went out just after the mural blackout.
Far end of Vyazemskaya, lots more pilots now.
People lost flight clearance after the score swings.
We flew without patrol interference—felt different.
Everyone talked about the Ledger fallout during setup.
Some folks hadn’t flown in months, too flagged.
It felt almost normal out there for once.
Yeah. I flew after the Ledger story broke, actually.
Most airfields are locked, but Vyazemskaya was open thanks to the system glitch.
A lot more people, not just regulars—some had just resurfaced after being ghosted.
Nobody cared about scores, just flying together while things were unstable.
We even shared tips on scrambling wristbands and re-syncing old transmitters.
Someone played mural testimonies on a local feed while we flew.
Honestly, best flight in ages—no patrols breathing down our necks.
People are talking more. Even swapping parts, like the old days.
Still at it. FPV’s the only time I forget about scores at all.
Last Sunday at Vyazemskaya was packed—half were flagged or resurfaced during the system chaos.
After the blackout, no patrol drones for hours. Everyone risked it, even those erased last year.
We streamed the mural voices live as we flew through the broken warehouses.
People are less scared to talk hardware again, tips on spoofing location, avoiding triggers.
Younger pilots shared how they’d dodged BCI sanctions, rebuilt from scraps.
Someone asked if it was ever this open before—honestly, no. Not since before Halden’s death.
For a while, nobody cared who you were or your clearance. Just flight.
Makes me think—flying’s always been about freedom, but now it means holding onto some piece of yourself.
